newsitem.title: USA: WMX, angry shareholders to square off at meeting.
newsitem.headline: WMX, angry shareholders to square off at meeting.

text.p: After trading charges in the media for months, WMX Technologies Inc. and dissatisfied major shareholders are scheduled to face off Friday at the company's long-awaited annual meeting.
Angry investors in the largest U.S. garbage hauling concern said they plan to attend the afternoon gathering in Oak Brook, Ill., and to press management on several issues.
Whether a floor battle will result appeared uncertain, however, due to recent defensive moves by the company, Wall Street analysts say.
"I think it will be uneventful," said Deutsche Morgan Grenfell industry analyst Mari Bari.

After months of demands from investors for better returns, WMX on Feb.4 announced a sweeping restructuring plan. Two weeks later, Chief Executive Phillip Rooney resigned under pressure. On April 18, Chairman Dean Buntrock said he would quit the company upon appointment of a new CEO.
"All this doesn't mean there won't be some angry presentations (at the meeting), but there's going to be a lot less bite in it," said Argus Research analyst James Kelleher.
Shares in WMX rose $1.125 to $31.25 on the New York Stock Exchange in afternoon trading.

Perhaps in vain, analysts said they hoped WMX would use the meeting as a timely forum for naming a new CEO. "The timing would be great. It seems, though, that it's early ... I'm not hearing a thing on it," said Smith Barney analyst Leone Young.

In the vaccum created by Rooney's surprise departure more than six weeks ago, analysts said employee morale at WMX has suffered and key mid-level managers are restless. "The resumes on other companies' desks are a foot thick," Bari said.
The stock has moved off nine-month lows since an April 21 first-quarter earnings report which, although flat on a year-over-year basis, at least met Wall Street expectations.
"We do think the stock could go up some when they announce the CEO," Bari said. "But we find the shares fairly valued on a fundamental basis over the long term."
Major investors who said they plan to attend Friday's meeting include a group led by U.S. financier George Soros, as well as Lens Fund, a Washington, D.C.-based investment group.
